sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: Each vial contains approximately 60 units.
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: 420 units (may use 840 units in severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.5 mL/min for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 1 mL/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 2 mL/min.
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: May consider repeat dosing in patients with substantial hemorrhage, significant compartmental fluid losses, or impaired or delayed immune response

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: Each vial contains approximately 60 units.
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; less than 5 kg): 60 units; infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; less than 10 kg): 60 units (may use 120 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 10 to less than 18 kg): 120 units (may use 240 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 18 to less than 25 kg): 180 units (may use 360 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 25 to less than 35 kg): 240 units (may use 480 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 35 to less than 50 kg): 300 units (may use 600 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 50 to less than 60 kg): 360 units (may use 720 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (Younger than 1 year through 16 years; 60 kg or greater): 420 units (may use 840 units for severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min) for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: (17 years): 420 units (may use 840 units in severe cases); infuse at a rate of 0.5 mL/min for the first 30 minutes, then increase infusion rate by 1 mL/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a MAX rate of 2 mL/min.
  • Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs: May consider repeat dosing in patients with substantial hemorrhage, significant compartmental fluid losses, or impaired or delayed immune response

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal insufficiency or at risk of developing renal insufficiency, any degree of impairment: Use minimum practicable infusion rate (not to exceed recommended infusion rate) and ensure adequate hydration before infusion.
  • Thrombosis risk: Use minimum practicable infusion rate and ensure adequate hydration before infusion.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Inhalational anthrax, In combination with appropriate antibacterial drugs

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Solution)
Falsely elevated blood glucose measurements may occur during therapy in diabetic patients because of the maltose ingredient; this increases the risk of masked hypoglycemic episodes and over administration of insulin, potentially causing life-threatening hypoglycemia. To avoid maltose interference, monitor blood glucose during therapy with glucose-specific methods (ie, monitor and test strips) in diabetic patients. Thrombosis may occur with or without known risk factors. Risk of thrombosis is increased with advanced age, prolonged immobilization, hypercoagulable conditions, history of venous or arterial thrombosis, estrogen use, indwelling central vascular catheters, hyperviscosity, and cardiovascular risk factors. For patients at risk of thrombosis, administer IVIG at the minimum dose and infusion rate practicable. Ensure adequate hydration in patients before administration. Monitor for signs and symptoms of thrombosis and assess blood viscosity in patients at risk for hyperviscosity.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Anaphylaxis or severe systemic reaction to human immunoglobulins
  • IgA deficiency with antibodies against IgA, and a history of hypersensitivity; IG products contain trace amounts of IgA

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Falsely elevated glucose measurements may occur in diabetic patients due to maltose ingredient, which increases the risk of masked hypoglycemic episodes and life-threatening hypoglycemia; monitoring with glucose-specific methods (ie, monitor and test strips) recommended
  • -- Thrombosis may occur; increased risk in the elderly, prolonged immobilization, cardiovascular risk factors, hypercoagulable conditions, hyperviscosity; reduction of dose may be necessary; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Hemolysis and hemolytic anemia may occur; severe hemolysis-related renal dysfunction or renal failure have been reported; increased risk with high doses (2 g/kg or greater), non-O blood group, and underlying inflammation; monitoring recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Infectious agent transmission may occur, including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as well as unknown or emerging viruses and other pathogens
  • -- Infusion reactions (ie, fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting) may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- Severe hypersensitivity reactions may occur; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if suspected
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Aseptic meningitis syndrome (AMS) may occur; increased risk with high doses (2 g/kg or greater) or rapid infusion; discontinuation may be necessary
  • Renal:
  • -- Acute renal dysfunction, acute renal failure, acute tubular necrosis, proximal tubular nephropathy, osmotic nephropathy, and death may occur; dosage adjustment may be necessary and monitoring recommended especially for patients with increased risk (eg, developing renal dysfunction, preexisting renal insufficiency, diabetes mellitus, volume depletion, sepsis, paraproteinemia, concomitant nephrotic drugs, or patients over 65 years)
  • -- Renal insufficiency; dose adjustments necessary
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Transfusion-related acute lung injury (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) may occur, usually with presenting symptoms within 1 to 6 hours of treatment; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (9.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (9.3%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (20.4%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Thrombosis
  • Hematologic:Hemolysis
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Renal:Acute renal failure, Renal impairment, acute
  • Respiratory:Transfusion related acute lung injury

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Anthrax immune globulin neutralizes anthrax toxin by binding to protective antigen and preventing protective antigen-mediated cellular entry of anthrax edema factor and lethal factor. It has no antibacterial activity against the anthrax bacteria, which may continue to grow and produce toxins.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Tmax, IV: 0.116 days (210 unit dose), 0.12 days (420 unit dose) and 0.169 days (840 unit dose)

1.title: Distribution
1.mono: Vd: 5714.8 mL (210 unit dose); 6837.2 mL (420 unit dose); 7238.2 mL (840 unit dose)

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Total body clearance: 174.2 mL/day (210 unit dose); 169.7 mL/day (420 unit dose); 188.6 mL/day (840 unit dose)

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: 24.3 days (210 unit dose); 28.3 days (420 unit dose); 28 days (840 unit dose)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    For IV use only
  • Intravenous
    • Thaw frozen vials by placing at room temperature for 1 hour then in water bath at 37 degrees C (98.6 degrees F) until thawed; alternatively, refrigerate at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F) until thawed (about 14 hours).
    • Do not use microwave to thaw vials; do not refreeze vials.
    • Thawed vials should be at room temperature before infusion.
    • Gently swirl vials by hand to ensure uniformity; do not shake.
    • Withdraw the vial content into a syringe and aseptically transfer into infusion bag immediately; administer as soon as possible.
    • Adult and pediatric patients 17 years old: Infuse at a rate of 0.5 mL/min for the first 30 minutes, then increase rate by 1 mL/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a maximum rate of 2 mL/min.
    • Pediatric patients (younger than 1 year through 16 years): Infuse at a rate of 0.01 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 0.5 mL/min), then increase rate by 0.02 mL/kg/min every 30 minutes (if tolerated) to a maximum rate of 0.04 mL/kg/min (not to exceed 2 mL/min).

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Clinical improvement indicates efficacy.
  • Renal function, at baseline and periodically thereafter
  • Urine output, periodically in patients at risk for acute renal failure
  • If blood glucose measurement is required, use glucose-specific testing to avoid maltose interference
  • Blood viscosity in patients at risk for hyperviscosity, at baseline
  • Hb or HCT in patients at higher risk for hemolysis, at baseline, within about 36 to 96 hours after infusion, and 7 to 10 days post-infusion; perform additional testing for signs or symptoms of hemolysis or substantial drop in Hb or HCT
  • Cerebrospinal fluid studies, in patients with signs and symptoms of aseptic meningitis syndrome
  • Anti-HLA and anti-neutrophil antibodies in product, if transfusion-related acute lung injury is suspected
  • Acute allergic reactions, during and after infusion, especially patients with antibodies against IgA
  • Signs and symptoms of infusion-related reactions, including vital signs, during and immediately after infusion
  • Signs and symptoms of thrombosis
  • Signs and symptoms of hemolysis and hemolytic anemia
  • Pulmonary adverse reactions and signs or symptoms of transfusion-related acute lung injury.
  • Neurological exam, in patients with signs and symptoms of aseptic meningitis syndrome

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to report symptoms of thrombosis or renal dysfunction.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of hemolytic anemia and hemolysis.
  • Direct patient to report symptoms of aseptic meningitis syndrome or transfusion-related acute lung injury.
  • Side effects may include headache, infusion site reactions, nausea, and back pain.
  • Tell diabetic patient to use glucose-specific monitoring methods due to potential for interference with some blood glucose testing systems.
  • Advise patient to delay live virus vaccinations for about 3 months after therapy due to potential for reduced efficacy.
